webTitle: Tesco bans sweets from checkouts in all stores

fields.bodyText: The UK's largest retailer, Tesco, is to ban sweets and chocolates from its checkouts after a survey of customers showed overwhelming support for the move. Research for Tesco found that 65% of shoppers wanted confectionery removed from checkouts to help them make healthier choices when shopping. Even more (67%) said it would help them choose healthier options for their children. Tesco removed sweets and chocolates from checkouts at its 740 larger Tesco stores 20 years ago, but they will now be removed from checkouts at all stores, including 1,800 Tesco Metro and Express convenience stores in Britain and Ireland. The retailer committed to removing them by the end of December 2014, but has brought forward the move after surveying its customers. Its chief executive, Philip Clarke, said the decision followed a commitment to make soft drinks, sandwiches and ready meals healthier by changing the recipes to reduce their sugar, salt and fat content. "We all know how easy it is to be tempted by sugary snacks at the checkout, and we want to help our customers lead healthier lives," Clarke said. Tesco was the first British supermarket to remove sweets and chocolates from checkouts at larger stores, in 1994. The retailer will now test a variety of healthier products at checkouts before implementing the full change across all stores. In January, Lidl banned confectionery from the checkout at all 600 of its British stores after surveying parents. It replaced racks of sweets with dried and fresh fruit, oatcakes and juices. Health campaigners and parents' groups welcomed Tesco's move. Katie O'Donovan of Mumsnet said: "Popping into a shop with a small child in tow can sometimes feel like navigating an assault course. If you've made it to the checkout in one piece it can be really frustrating to then be faced with an unhealthy array of sweets designed to tempt your child. It's really positive to see a supermarket responding to the views of their customers and trying to make life that little bit easier." Ben Reynolds of the food and health charity Sustain agreed. "Parents will be delighted to hear that they will no longer be pestered for fatty, salty and sugary snacks while queuing at the checkout in their local Tesco. We hope that other supermarkets will now follow Lidl and Tesco's lead, and realise that taking action to improve children's health is not something to fear." Tesco was among those criticised in research published in January which found that convenience stores run by big supermarket chains involved in the government's responsibility deal on nutrition were exposing children to displays of sweets and snack food at the checkout. Researchers from Sheffield University visited the smaller stores of Asda, Sainsbury's and Tesco in the city and discovered what harassed parents often complain of – that the queue for the checkout often passes shelves laden with chocolate bars, drinks and sweet snacks at children's eye level.

webTitle: Over 100 arrested near McDonald's headquarters in protest over low pay

fields.bodyText: McDonald’s closed part of its corporate headquarters on Wednesday in response to a mass protest by workers and activists that campaigners say ended in more than 100 arrests. Over 2,000 people calling for a hike in the minimum wage and the right to form a union without retaliation descended on the fast food giant’s suburban Chicago headquarters in what is believed to be the largest demonstration McDonald’s has ever faced. Chanting, “Hey McDonald’s You Can’t Hide, We Can See Your Greedy Side,” and “No Big Macs, No Fries, Make our Wage Supersize,” protesters blocked the entrance to McDonald’s campus in Oakbrook, some 20 miles outside Chicago. A short walk from Hamburger University, McDonald’s training center, the protesters were confronted by a phalanx of police officers in riot gear. After they sat down the police issued two orders to disperse and arrests began. Police said 101 McDonald's workers and 38 community supporters were arrested. McDonald’s workers, church leaders and Service Employees International Union president Mary Kay Henry were among those arrested. Some 500 fast-food workers from three dozen cities as well as local church groups, union activists and community groups were present at the demonstration. It came a day before the fast food company’s annual meeting when dissident shareholders intend to vote against CEO Donald Thompson’s $9.5m pay package. Protesters also plan to picket that meeting, from which media have been excluded. Activists said the company feared a "public relations minefield" and had sent workers home in order to derail the protest. Protesters moved their demonstration to another nearby McDonald’s corporate facility. A McDonald's spokeswoman said the company had taken the decision to close the a building on its campus that holds 2,000 staff after consultation with police. The building was close to a busy intersection and the company was concerned about the disruption the protesters could cause to traffic. She said staff continued to work from home. Restaurant and retail workers are calling for a minimum wage of $15 per hour. The latest protest is one of a series aimed at fueling a national debate on income inequality and comes after a report from the Demos thinktank showed that fast-food companies had the largest gap between the pay of CEOs and workers of any industry. The report found that the CEO-to-worker compensation ratio for the fast-food industry was more than 1,000-to-one in 2013. Amanda Wenninghoff, 28, has been working for McDonald’s in Kansas City for 10 years and travelled to Chicago to call for a wage rise. She earns $8 an hour and said she hadn’t had a wage raise since 2003. “I have lived in my car with my kids because I haven’t had the wages to support a place for us to live,” she told the Guardian. “I have friends who need life-saving surgery they can’t afford.” She said McDonald’s offered health insurance, but it would cost $400 a month for her alone –about half her monthly salary. “It would be impossible for me to get by without government assistance,” she said. “The least they can do is pay us enough money so we can afford to live instead of putting it on the taxpayers.” McDonald’s worker Ashona Osborne, 24, travelled from Pittsburgh to protest. She makes $7.25 an hour and said her wages had been cut since she had started to protest. “I need better support for me and my family,” she said. “It’s not just McDonald’s, I have been working on minimum wage since I was 16 and it’s very, very difficult. I have decide which priority to take care of, which bill can I pay.” She said Thompson $9.5m pay package worked out at about $6,600 an hour. “He makes more money than me on the way to work,” she said. “That’s ridiculous. They can afford to give me more money. If it weren’t for us workers there would be no McDonald’s, no Burger King, no Wendy’s.” On Thursday, shareholder activist Change to Win Investment Group (Ctw) is organising a vote against Thompson, who took over as CEO in 2012. It follows similar protests against CEO pay at other restaurant groups including Domino’s and Chipotle. Earlier this month, 77% of Chipotle shareholders voted against the compensation packages of co-CEOs Steve Ells and Monty Moran, worth $25.1m and $24.4m respectively in 2013. The vote, which is non-binding and was also organised by CtW, has prompted a review of compensation at the company. The pressure for change comes as President Obama has pushed Congress to raise the federal minimum wage to $10.10 per hour from the current $7.25. The move is being challenged by Republicans and by lobbyists for the restaurant industry who claim it will cost jobs. The Bureau of Labor Statistics calculates that there are 3.5m fast-food and counter workers in the US, and they earn a median hourly wage of $8.83 – almost $18,400 per year based on a 40-hour work week without vacation. Earlier this year the Congressional Budget Office said a hike in the minimum wage to $10.10 would cost 500,000 jobs by 2016 but boost earnings for about 16.5 million low-wage workers. The National Restaurant Association said the report was proof that a wage hike was detrimental for the economy. “The restaurant industry provides real pathways to the middle class and beyond, and dramatic increases in the minimum wage will only hinder our ability to provide stepping stones for those who need it most,” the association said in a statement.

webTitle: AstraZeneca directors unmoved by shareholder calls to reopen Pfizer talks

fields.bodyText: AstraZeneca's directors remained defiant on Wednesday night in the face of calls from one of the drugs company's biggest shareholders to reopen talks with its unwanted suitor, the US-based Pfizer group. With less than five days left until the 5pm deadline on Monday when Pfizer has to table a firm offer or walk away for six months, AXA Investment Managers and Legal & General expressed disappointment with AstraZeneca's refusal to negotiate with its US rival. While Astra's management were hoping that their rejection of Pfizer's increased £55-a-share bid proposal, tabled on Sunday, would end the US group's ambitions, some investors in the Anglo-Swedish company remain keen for a deal to be agreed. Even though one key investor, Threadneedle Asset Management, threw its weight behind the Astra board, most of the focus in the City was on a report in the Wall Street Journal saying that Legal & General, AstraZeneca's sixth-largest shareholder with 3.4% of the UK firm, had written to AstraZeneca demanding they go back to the negotiating table. Legal & General refused to deny the report. Pfizer cannot raise its offer under UK takeover rules before Monday and has ruled out going hostile. But it is understood to be working behind the scenes to get investors to express their anger. AstraZeneca shares rose 2.6% to £44.20 amid hopes a deal could still happen this year, while investment bank UBS raised AstraZeneca's standalone value to £50 a share. Jim Stride, head of UK equities at AXA Investment Managers, which holds a 0.89% stake in AstraZeneca, said the board was "arguably wrong and acted too hastily to dismiss the latest proposal from Pfizer". He added: "It is the view of AXA IM UK that the board of AstraZeneca should not prevent an offer from Pfizer of £55 per share from being put to the shareholders of the company. Many shareholders – but not necessarily all – will find this an attractive offer." Other parts of the AXA insurance group, which own at least another 3% of AstraZeneca, could share Stride's views, but the insurer refused to comment. Stride's statement came after Threadneedle Asset Management, with a 1.5% stake in AstraZeneca, publicly backed the board. "We feel the full implications of the proposed acquisition have not been sufficiently understood and addressed by Pfizer. The company has made notable progress under Pascal Soriot and is a strong, standalone UK business with a good product pipeline." Sweden's Investor AB, with a 4.1% stake, Aberdeen Asset Management, M&G, Fidelity and Neil Woodford, the influential City investor who controls a £350m stake on behalf of St James's Place, have all voiced support of AstraZeneca. Together they control more than 10% of AstraZeneca shares. Among the "rebels", Schroders, which is AstraZeneca's 12th-biggest shareholder, Schafer Cullen Capital Management, a New York-based investment firm that controls a 1.5% stake on behalf of clients, and Jupiter Asset Management have all expressed disappointment at AstraZeneca's refusal to negotiate. Those who have spoken out against the board control about 7% of AstraZeneca shares, but have not mounted a coordinated action. One suggestion circulating was that they could call an extraordinary general meeting to put Pfizer's offer to a vote. The support of just 5% of holders of AstraZeneca stock is needed to call an extraordinary general meeting, but it could not take place before next Monday's deadline. If an EGM was held after the deadline, shareholders could force AstraZeneca to reopen talks with Pfizer in late August after the obligatory three-month cooling-off period. Shareholders angry at AstraZeneca's refusal to engage further with Pfizer have so far outlined no specific proposals that would enable a deal to happen within the takeover rules. But one possibility put forward by analysts is that AstraZeneca could recommend the £55-a-share proposal on the understanding that it would pay a big special dividend, agreed with Pfizer, when the deal completed. Such a plan would in effect increase the payout to shareholders – but it would probably be in breach of UK takeover rules. AstraZeneca has been clear in its rejection of Pfizer's offer and a U-turn by the board appears very unlikely. As part of its defence strategy Astra Zeneca has talked up its pipeline of potential cancer treatments and predicted a 75% jump in annual revenues to more than $45bn by 2023. However, Pfizer's former top scientist John LaMattina, who spent 30 years at the New York drugmaker, questioned AstraZeneca's ability to meet its targets. "Ironically, to reach his sales target, Soriot himself may need to do a merger," he said. Unions representing workers at AstraZeneca's sites in Macclesfield backed the company's rejection of the Pfizer bid and called for a meeting with Soriot to discuss job prospects. They said: "Union representatives call on the board to face down pressure from all quarters to get into negotiations with Pfizer for an agreed bid and to brace to fight any hostile bid." • This article was amended on 22 May

webTitle: Burberry's 'allowance' for Bailey means transparency is still out of fashion

fields.bodyText: "My new role is an unconventional role and my background is not one of a traditional CEO," declared Christopher Bailey as he set out his stall as the new boss of Burberry. Fair enough. He may be a breath of fresh air, and it should not be remarkable that a fashion company has chosen to appoint its creative guru as its chief executive. But it would be a disgrace if a healthy disregard for convention is used to excuse the award to Bailey of a mysterious £440,000 annual "allowance". It's not as if he's badly paid on the normal stuff. He'll get a £1.1m salary, the chance to earn a £2.2m bonus every year. And promotion yielded a performance-related golden hello in the form of £7.6m in shares. So what's the "allowance" meant to cover? Burberry refuses to say. Is Bailey permitted to spend the sum, which works out at £1,235 a day, as he wishes? If so, it's a second salary, in non-pensionable form, and Burberry is silly to pretend otherwise. If the £440,000 is meant to cover the necessity of wearing Burberry clothes, does Bailey really need a new outfit every day? The great man himself is not taking questions. He declined to speak to the press on the day Burberry announced its full-year results. That, presumably, is another quirk of his "unconventional" approach to the job. Actually, though, it's Sir John Peace, Burberry chairman, and Ian Carter, head of the remuneration committee, who should explain the "allowance". Most FTSE 100 companies are shifting towards greater transparency on pay but Burberry seems to be running in the opposite direction. Standard Chartered, where Peace is also chairman, suffered a 41% rebellion on its pay policy the other week and fund managers complain about the bank's arrogant approach to communications. Peace, it seems, has learned nothing from that episode.

webTitle: Retail sales up 6.9% in April, making early rate rise likely

fields.bodyText: Retailers enjoyed their best month for a decade in April, with sales up 6.9% on the same month a year ago, providing further evidence of recovery and raising the prospects for an early interest-rate rise. Figures from the Office for National Statistics showed the volume of sales rose 1.3% on March levels, boosted by spending during Easter in the shops and online last month. The housing market, which had showed some signs of slowing in February and March, regained its previous momentum in April as buyers increased their borrowing, undeterred by tighter restrictions on mortgage loans put in place by the City's consumer watchdog. The Council of Mortgage Lenders said gross mortgage lending amounted to £16.6bn last month, up 8% on March and more than a third higher than the same time last year. Investors reacted to the news, which comes ahead of revised GDP figures that are expected to confirm the UK as the fastest growing of the major developed nations, by pushing the pound higher against the dollar and the euro. But the resurgence in high street spending and stronger-than-expected housebuying activity immediately sparked concerns that the Bank of England will be forced to raise interest rates to prevent the economy overheating. The Bank has come under intense pressure from some City institutions to raise rates since the economy began to recover early last year. Until recently the Bank's monetary policy committee, which sets interest-rate policy, has insisted that rates needed to stay at historic lows until unemployment fell to nearer its long-term average and wages increased consistently above inflation. Economists had expected the Bank to begin raising rates early next year. However, the minutes of the MPC's meeting earlier this month revealed the first signs of a split among policymakers as disagreements flared over the strength of the recovery and when to lift rates back to more normal levels. A speech by outgoing deputy governor Charlie Bean earlier this week added to the tension when he said regulatory tools designed to calm the housing market may not work and the central bank may be unable to resist rasing rates to prevent a bubble. Carney said in a recent TV interview that the housing market posed the biggest threat to the long term health of the economy. Several MPC members have voiced concerns that forecasts of a moderation in consumer spending and housebuying could prove too pessimistic. Figures from financial data provider Markit appeared to justify their position, showing that households were more confident in April about the outlook for their finances than at any time in the past five years. The survey found that more households no longer fear redundancy and more expect their incomes to rise than since 2009. Economists said rising confidence and a bounce back from poor weather in March pushed retail sales in the latest quarter – considered a better guide to the underlying trend than one month's figures – up 1.8% on the previous three months. Both the annual and the quarterly increases were the highest since the spring of 2004. The ONS said there had been an across-the-board increase in sales last month, with food stores posting their strongest annual growth rates in 12 years. Retailers enjoyed their best month for a decade in April, with sales up 6.9% on the same month a year ago, providing further evidence of recovery and raising the prospects for an early interest-rate rise.

Figures from the Office for National Statistics showed the volume of sales rose 1.3% on March levels, boosted by spending during Easter in the shops and online last month.

The housing market, which had showed some signs of slowing in February and March, regained its previous momentum in April as buyers increased their borrowing, undeterred by tighter restrictions on mortgage loans put in place by the City's consumer watchdog.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders said gross mortgage lending amounted to £16.6bn last month, up 8% on March and more than a third higher than the same time last year.

Investors reacted to the news, which comes ahead of revised GDP figures that are expected to confirm the UK as the fastest growing of the major developed nations, by pushing the pound higher against the dollar and the euro.

But the resurgence in high street spending and stronger-than-expected housebuying activity immediately sparked concerns that the Bank of England will be forced to raise interest rates to prevent the economy overheating.

The Bank has come under intense pressure from some City institutions to raise rates since the economy began to recover early last year. Until recently the Bank's monetary policy committee, which sets interest-rate policy, has insisted that rates needed to stay at historic lows until unemployment fell to nearer its long-term average and wages increased consistently above inflation.

Economists had expected the Bank to begin raising rates early next year. However, the minutes of the MPC's meeting earlier this month revealed the first signs of a split among policymakers as disagreements flared over the strength of the recovery and when to lift rates back to more normal levels.

A speech by outgoing deputy governor Charlie Bean earlier this week added to the tension when he said regulatory tools designed to calm the housing market may not work and the central bank may be unable to resist rasing rates to prevent a bubble. Carney said in a recent TV interview that the housing market posed the biggest threat to the long term health of the economy.

Several MPC members have voiced concerns that forecasts of a moderation in consumer spending and housebuying could prove too pessimistic.

Figures from financial data provider Markit appeared to justify their position, showing that households were more confident in April about the outlook for their finances than at any time in the past five years. The survey found that more households no longer fear redundancy and more expect their incomes to rise than since 2009.

This bodes very well for GDP growth in the second quarter."

webTitle: Lloyds closes Warrington call centre as 645 jobs go

fields.standfirst: Redundancy total since António Horta-Osório took the helm in March 2011 reaches 13,055
fields.body:
Lloyds Banking Group has blamed the closure of a call centre in Warrington – part of an announcement of 645 job cuts – on customers preferring to bank online. Call volumes are down 11% so far this year, although trade unions have warned that the job losses risked damaging customer service.

The 645 job cuts take the number lost since António Horta-Osório took the helm of the bank in 2011 to 13,055. He has earmarked 15,000 cuts as part of a three-year strategy, on top of 30,000 lost as a result of Lloyds TSB's rescue of HBOS in 2008 to create the larger group.

About 180 jobs are going from Warrington – which will close – with 120 moving to Speke, Liverpool. In total 645 jobs are going across several areas, although 65 will be created.

"This is the third tranche of job losses since the beginning of the year and is in danger of sending staff morale to an all-time low," said Rob MacGregor, of Unite. "The closure of the Warrington centre will hit the local economy and risks damaging customer service," he added. Officials at the Accord union said there was "no end in sight" for job cuts.

A Lloyds spokesperson said: "Telephone banking call volumes are falling as digital banking continues to grow, and we are refocusing the business to reflect these changes in our customers' habits, while ensuring we maintain our high standards for those who wish to continue using our telephone banking systems by bringing our telephone banking colleagues together at fewer, more specialised sites."

webTitle: Saga cuts flotation price to around £2bn from previous £2.5bn estimate

fields.standfirst: The over 50s holidays and insurance group announced it would join the stock market earlier this month
fields.body:
Over 50s holidays and insurance group Saga has cut back the price of its forthcoming stock market flotation to around £2bn.

The valuation is less than the £2.5bn that had been estimated when it first announced its intention to join the stock market earlier this month.

The share sale is to be priced at between 185 and 205 pence a share, down from the 185 to 245 pence previously estimated.

A source said the company's cautious approach to pricing came from its keenness to avoid the share price slide which has plagued companies such as Poundland and Just Eat since their listings this year.

The new guidance gives the company a value of between £2bn and £2.2bn, said a separate source familiar with the deal, lower than the original price range which valued the company at up to £2.5bn .

A low price range can indicate a lack of demand from investors. However Saga, which has offered a retail allocation to its loyal base of 2.1 million customers, said it had experienced "exceptional" demand for its retail offering.

"Given our desire to allow customers to play a significant part in the future ownership of the business, we remain very focused on seeking to underpin a positive after-market performance in the stock," said executive chairman Andrew Goodsell.

Shares in the company, which started as a travel company in Folkestone and extended into insurance, are due to begin trading on 29 May.

Charterhouse Capital Partners, CVC and Permira, which have owned Saga's parent firm since 2007, will sell stakes during the float.

• Bank of England: MPC members express a variety of views
  • Retail sales jump 6.9%
  • What does it mean for interest rates? - experts have their say
  • Threadneedle backs AstraZeneca board..
  • ..but L&G 'write to Astra' demanding Pfizer talks
fields.body:
5.49pm BST

Markets end higher after recent volatlity

Better economic news - such as UK retail sales - and an opening rise on Wall Street ahead of the latest US Federal Reserve minutes has given markets a lift. The closing scores showed:

• The FTSE 100 finished 19.04 points or 0.28% higher at 6821.04

• Germany's Dax ended 0.61% better at 9697.87

• France's Cac closed up 0.37% at 4469.03

• Italy's FTSE MIB added 1.07% to 20,597.51

• Spain's Ibex rose 0.74% to 10,531.4

On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently up 124 points or 0.76%.

On that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.49pm BST

5.29pm BST

Even since European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's press conference earlier this month, there has been much speculation that the central bank will move in June to tackle low inflation, perhaps by cutting interest rates or even some form of quantitative easing.

But Bundesbank president and ECB governing council member Jens Weidmann has said it is not clear whether the bank will actually have to act in June. In an interview with Sueddeutsche Zeitung due to be published tomorrow (via Reuters) he said the ECB's loose monetary policy stance was appropriate to support the recovery but the risks should be borne in mind. He said:

The interest rate policy is the core of our monetary policy instruments. A central banker's attention would certainly focus first on this, if in the end it became necessary to act.

But so far it is not clear whether we will have to act at all.

5.25pm BST

Unions representing AstraZeneca's sites in Macclesfield have backed the company's rejection of the Pfizer bid and called for a meeting with chief executive Pascal Soriot to discuss job prospects. A statement from the GMB and Unite shop stewards said:

Union representatives expressed full support the AstraZeneca board decision to reject the Pfizer bid.

Union representatives call on the board to face down pressure from all quarters to get into negotiations with Pfizer for an agreed bid and to brace to fight any hostile bid.

Union representatives are seeking a meeting with Pascal Soriot....to follow up on evidence he gave to the BIS Committee in Parliament on 13 May on job prospects in Astra Zeneca.

5.09pm BST

Oops. AXA Group may own a large chunk of AstraZeneca but AXA Investment Managers - which earlier came out against the board - only has a 0.89% holding. It has just issued a "clarification" as follows:

In response to a number of enquiries, we would like to emphasise that today’s statement represents the views of AXA Investment Managers UK, which has a 0.89% holding in AstraZeneca.

AXA IM UK is part of AXA Group, which in aggregate has a larger holding in AstraZeneca; however this statement has been issued on behalf of AXA IM UK only.

Updated at 5.45pm BST

4.40pm BST

Back with AstraZeneca, and here's someone backing the board against the Pfizer bid. Jill Treanor writes:

Jeremy Whitley, head of UK and European equities at Aberdeen Asset Management, is supportive of the approach taking by the AstraZeneca board. However he does not rule out Pfizer coming back in the future and makes clear that the Astra board is now under pressure to deliver on its promises."We think the Astra board have done a very good job to get the best value they can," Whitley said. "Deep down do we think this is very best offer? [If not] we can be patient".

"The pressure is now on the AstraZeneca board to deliver," he said, adding that the board of the pharmaceuticals company was best placed to put a valuation on its drugs pipeline. The company has used its prediction of $45bn of annual revenues by 2023 as key reason to fend off Pfizer's approach.

4.06pm BST

Over to Greece where the political temperature is rising ahead of a second round of local European elections this weekend. Helena Smith reports:

Greece heads to elections this weekend in brittle mood. As Giorgos Kaminis and Gabriel Sakellarides, the two candidates for the Athens mayoralty prepare to face each other in a live debate this evening, it is Golden Dawn, the far right party which has blossomed with the country’s economic crisis, that is dominating events. The extremist group’s surprisingly strong performance in the first round of last Sunday’s local and regional elections – at 16.1 % its own candidate for mayor Ilias Kasidiaris more than doubled the party’s 6.9% showing in national elections in 2012 – has sparked concerns across the political spectrum. Deputy prime minister Evangelos Venizelos, who heads the coalition government’s junior partner, Pasok, called the showing “deeply worrying.” “The big democratic question is the high percentages of Golden Dawn in the municipality of Athens and the Attica prefecture,” he said. “It is the urgent duty of all citizens and social forces that believe in democracy and human rights to forcefully fight the fascist-ization of political life.”

But political expediency, ahead of Sunday’s runoff local ballot, has resulted in what today’s centre-left Ta Nea described as “surreptitious flirting” with Golden Dawn. Sakellarides, candidate for the vehemently anti-austerity radical left Syriza party in the race for Athens’ Town Hall, has (in a first for the left) gone out of his way to distinguish those who voted for Golden Dawn from the party itself. “We are not opening up to neo-Nazis … the 16 % of Athenians who voted for Kasidiaris are not neo-Nazis” he said before appealing to them to “change their mind” about how they would “protest about the situation we are living today.”

Analysts are now in no doubt that it is the economy that poses the greatest challenge for the government. Despite the encouraging signs Greece has shown of late – its return to international markets, its improved fiscal figures and attraction of record numbers of tourists – Golden Dawn has capitalized on the seething resentment and rage of those now wanting to punish a system seen as the genesis of everything that is wrong with Greece.

The middle class, which has been brought to its knees by the collapse of small and medium sized businesses, a barrage of taxes and the highest unemployment rate in the EU, has moved shockingly towards Golden Dawn with the governing centre right New Democracy party losing most to the extremists. Despite the imprisonment of a third of its leaders - and a judicial investigation that has focused on its underground activities as a criminal organization – the neo-fascists took around 9 % nationwide in Sunday’s poll. More shocking still, the group attracted large levels of support in bourgeois areas of the capital such as Kolonaki where backing for the party reached 13.7 %. “Golden Dawn’s appeal is no longer based on the anti-immigrant vote, it’s all about the economy,” said the political commentator Giorgos Kyrtsos, a New Democracy candidate in the upcoming euro elections. “If there is not a dynamic development of the economy in the next four to five months, after the tourist season, we will be in big, big trouble.”

3.18pm BST

The stronger than expected eurozone consumer confidence figures will not necessarily stop the European Central Bank from acting next month, perhaps with an interest rate cut, analysts reckon. Martin van Vliet at ING said:

The further brightening in consumers’ economic mood bodes well for consumer spending growth in the second quarter – and will undoubtedly be greeted with enthusiasm in Brussels ahead of this week's European parliamentary elections.

However, consumer spending across the eurozone, albeit improving, has consistently lagged the recovery in consumer confidence in recent quarters. Consequently, we remain cautious on the strength of the upturn in consumer spending, with household deleveraging and subdued real disposable income growth set to continue to act as restraining factors.

So while it is encouraging to see confidence continuing to move in the right direction, this is unlikely to stop the ECB from implementing further easing measures next month. The country breakdown is not yet available for May, but the confidence recovery in the Eurozone has not been confined to Northern European countries. Sentiment in most Southern European countries has also recovered strongly, despite the ongoing high unemployment backdrop.

Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight said:

Encouraging news for eurozone growth prospects with consumer confidence extending its upward trend in May and rising markedly to be at its highest level since October 2007. This suggests that the Ukraine/Russia crisis has still not worried consumers unduly, although it does appear to have impacted on business confidence in some countries, notably Germany.

While the ECB will be encouraged by the marked rise in eurozone consumer confidence in May and may well see it as indicating that modest eurozone recovery remains intact despite disappointing GDP growth of 0.2% quarter-on-quarter in the first quarter, it is does not make it any less likely that the ECB will cut all of its interest rates at its June meeting (including taking the deposit rate into negative territory), very possibly as part of a package of stimulative measures aimed at preventing prolonged very low eurozone consumer price inflation and softening the euro.

3.04pm BST

Back with the eurozone, and consumer confidence for May rose to its highest level in six and a half years.

The European Commission's first estimate showed a figure of -7.1 points compared to April's revised -8.6 and expectations of an improvement to -8.2.

For the whole of the EU, consumer confidence improved by 1.6 points to -4.1.

2.40pm BST

Axa Investment Managers has become the latest to come out against AstraZeneca's rejection of the £55 a share Pfizer bid.

Axa owns 4.5% and is the third biggest shareholder in Astra. Jim Stride, director and head of UK equities, said:

AXA Investment Managers UK, acting in accordance with its fiduciary duty to clients, has met with the management teams of Pfizer and AstraZeneca in the recent past. We have also engaged in ongoing written and verbal communication.

It is the view of AXA IM UK that the board of AstraZeneca should not prevent an offer from Pfizer of £55 per share from being put to the shareholders of the company. Many shareholders – but not necessarily all – will find this an attractive offer. Accordingly we believe that the board was arguably wrong and acted too hastily to dismiss the latest proposal from Pfizer.

2.20pm BST

Saga has cut its flotation price range following the closure of the retail offer on Tuesday.

The company, which provides insurance and holidays for the over-50s, said the range would now be 185p to 245p a share, compared to the original top end of 245p. This is apparently to support "a strong debut."

Adam Jepsen, Director, Capital Spreads, said:

Capital Spreads earlier this week reported a fall in the grey market price for Saga. Director Adam Jepsen said:

We have seen a fairly significant fall on our grey market – Saga has gone from a valuation of £3.25bn to around £2.4bn in the space of a week. This is not so much a reflection of concerns over Saga’s attractiveness as an investment, but more an issue around the number of shares on offer.

Based on the 1.07bn shares due to be issued, according to the listing documents, and on the assumption that all shares are equal, on Capital Spreads’ current spread the share price would be between 210p and 238p at the end of the first day’s trading.

Updated at 2.23pm BST

1.55pm BST

Reuters: Vast majority of economists expect ECB to cut rates in June

Reuters has polled City economists and found that the "vast majority" believe the European Central Bank will cut its headline borrowing rate to a new record low of 0.1% at its June meeting.

Most also expect the ECB will impose negative interest rates on European banks, by cutting its deposit rate from 0.0% to -0.1%.

1.24pm BST

Another day, another recall at General Motors.

Associated Press is reporting that GM has added 218,000 subcompact cars to its growing list of recalled vehicles -- to fix a glitch that could lead to a fire.

The new recall covers certain Chevrolet Aveo cars from the 2004 through 2008 model years. GM says the daytime running light module in the dashboard center stack can overheat, melt and cause fires.

Yesterday, GM recalled 2.4 million vehicles -- today's news means the number of cars called back to have problems fixed has hit 13.8 million in 2014 alone.

Updated at 1.24pm BST

1.11pm BST

Today could be dubbed Minutes Wednesday - with the US Federal Reserve releasing the notes from its own monetary policy committee meeting later today (7pm UK time, or 2pm New York).

The FOMC minutes will give fesh insight into when US borrowing costs might rise.

Analysts at RANsquawk reckon we'll hear that "a range of views" were expressed (rather like at the Bank of England).

Their video preview explains all:

12.53pm BST

After almost a year, Mark Carney's honeymoon at the Bank of England is well and truly over, with senior policymakers prepared to disagree over how to tackle monetary policy.

The minutes of this month's meeting show MPC members had the resolve to express "a variety of views on the appropriate path of monetary policy".

Writing in the Times (£, sorry), Phillip Aldrick argues that Carney is now in new territory. Dissent is back at the Bank:

A ten-month unconditional love-in with the new Bank of England governor appears to have been all Britain’s independent rate-setters could stomach. The unity of the nine-strong Monetary Policy Committee is finally beginning to crack.

But as he concludes, argument is a good thing:

The fact that there is a real debate once again over the most critical policy instrument in the UK should be celebrated.

Reminder, the minutes are online here (pdf).

MPC members are now freer to think for themselves because the UK unemployment rate has fallen below 7%.

That's the level Carney identified as a threshold last August in his first stab at forward guidance (now torn up and replaced with a woollier policy based on guessing how much slack remains in the labour market).

12.27pm BST

Here's economics editor Larry Elliott's take on this morning's strong retail sales figure:

Britain's retailers are enjoying their best trading conditions for a decade after low interest rates, rising confidence, a booming housing market and a late Easter boosted spending in the shops and online last month....

UK retailers buoyed by best trading conditions in a decade

Updated at 12.27pm BST

12.18pm BST

The cutbacks in Britain's banking sector continues --with Lloyds eliminating another 645 roles in the UK and closing its Warrington telephone banking centre.

The Unite union warns that staff morale could hit an 'all-time low', as this is the third round of job losses in 2014. It urges Lloyds to avoid compulsory job losses.

Unite national officer Rob MacGregor warned that Lloyds customers could also suffer from the cuts:

“The closure of the Warrington centre will hit the local economy and risks damaging customer service.

“Lloyds staff have worked hard since it was bailed out by the taxpayer to make the bank a success. Their reward has been continual uncertainty and attacks on their pensions.

“Lloyds needs to give its workforce stability and guarantees of no compulsory redundancies. Only then will the bank be able to live up to its motto to ‘Make Britain Prosper’.”

12.08pm BST

The Wall Street Journal has now published the story about how Legal & General has written to AstraZeneca to call for fresh talks with Pfizer (as flagged at 11.31am).

Legal & General Urges AstraZeneca to Engage With Pfizer

AstraZeneca sixth-largest investor, Legal & General Group PLC, is urging the U.K. drug giant's board to reverse its rejection of a $120 billion takeover offer from Pfizer and engage in talks, two people familiar with the situation said.

The investment arm of the U.K. insurer, which holds a 3.5% stake in AstraZeneca, has written to the company's board asking it to engage in talks with Pfizer, one of the people said. Legal & General declined to comment. AstraZeneca declined to comment on individual shareholder interactions but said it is continuing to engage in general with its investors.

Legal & General joins AXA, Schroders, and Jupiter Fund Management as large AstraZeneca investors that have publicly expressed disappointment at its rejection of the offer. Combined, they hold around 7% of the stock.

More here.

Astra shares are currently 1.5% higher, at £43.77.

11.59am BST

After years of relative tedium, the Bank of England's monthly monetary policy committee meetings are going to be a lot more exciting as pressure grows to raise rates.

Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, says there are "emerging signs of disagreement in April’s meeting" in today's BoE minutes.

“The debate on interest rates looks set to become more heated. According to the latest minutes of the MPC, while the Committee remained unanimous in favour of keeping policy of hold, there were a variety of views on the appropriate path of monetary policy. For some members the decision to keep rates unchanged was becoming ‘more balanced’.

That said, with prospects for inflation looking very benign and the economy, in our view, possessing a significant amount of spare capacity, we still think that a rate rise will not happen until well into 2015."

11.31am BST

AstraZeneca shares have leading the FTSE 100 risers, gaining 1.8% this morning to £43.83.

The trigger appears to be a report that one of Astra's biggest shareholders, Legal & General, has written to the company's board urging them to re-open talks with Pfizer over its £55 per share offer.

It's being attributed to Dow Jones Newswires - I've not managed to find it myself, yet, I'm afraid.

We just spoke to L&G and they declined to comment....

(as reported at 10.40am, Threadneedle Asset Management have told us they support Astra's board today)

Updated at 11.37am BST

11.02am BST

Bank minutes and Retail sales: what the experts say

There's masses of reaction to the surge in UK retail sales last month, and the evidence that some Bank of England policymakers are inching towards raising interest rates.

Many experts are pondering what its means for borrowing costs - when will rates be risen above the 0.5% record low?

Heres some of the best comment out there:

James Knightley of ING:

With the growth story broadening out we are getting closer to a rate rise from the Bank of England. Our house view remains that the first hike will probably come in February, but given the strength in growth, employment and asset prices the risks are skewed towards a slightly earlier move.

If we see wages growth pick up – note the impending 3% rise in national minimum wage and the increase in reported pay awards – then we would be more inclined to bring it forward.

Rob Wood of Berenberg Bank says today' minutes are 'less dovish', and could herald a rate rise before Christmas

Retail sales posted an exceptionally strong 6.9% yoy growth rate in April. That was obviously distorted by the timing of Easter, so the growth rate will drop back sharply next month.

But the reading was way ahead of consensus expectations. These data support our forecasts for above consensus growth and a first rate hike coming in the first quarter of 2015. We see a 35% chance that the BoE hikes in the fourth quarter of 2014.

The UK economy is motoring, fuelled for now by consumption, and the BoE rate setters are shifting their views in response.

Alex Edwards, head of the corporate desk at UKForex, agrees we could see an interest rate rise before Christmas. Here's why:

UK Retail Sales have yet again beaten expectations with a month-on-month jump of 1.3%, far exceeding the forecast of 0.4%.

All stores except petrol stations have seen an increase in sales with April ’14 showing an increase of 6.9% from April ’13. With UK house prices continuing to rise and CPI starting to accelerate, the MPC may be forced to bring forward an interest rate rise to Q4 2014.

February 2015 is a popular bet:

Analysts at Abshire-Smith say:

Traders have been betting that the BoE will be forced to raise interest rates sooner than expected, as the economic growth begins to pick up pace and to cool a potential property bubble.

But Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight reckons it's "far from clear" when rates will rise. One reson - the committee is changing this summer (when Nemat Shafik and Kristin Forbes join the MPC)

The outlook for monetary policy is starting to look a lot more uncertain, with the minutes of the May MPC meeting indicating that opinions within the committee are diverging on about exactly when monetary policy should start to be gradually tightened. There are clear indications in the May minutes that some of the more hawkish MPC members are starting to get twitchy.

The longer-term message from the Bank of England remains that when interest rates do start to rise, the increases will be gradual and limited, but when exactly the first increase comes is far from clear.

Updated at 11.13am BST

10.40am BST

Threadneedle Asset Management backs AstraZeneca board

As recriminations fly over Pfizer's failing bid for AstraZeneca, one of the UK drugs firm's larger shareholders has told the Guardian that they still support Astra's top management.

Iain Richards, head of responsible investment at Threadneedle Asset Management, said:

"As long-term shareholders we continue to be supportive of the AstraZeneca board".

Threadneedle has a 1.5% stake in the company - making it Astra's 15th-largest shareholder.

Last night, AstraZeneca issued a statement to the City insisting that Pfizer's £55 per share 'final' offer cannot be raised again, with or without Astra's approval.

Yesterday, Schroders expressed 'disappointment' with both companies, but other shareholders -- such as Neil Woodford -- have backed Astra. There's still talk of rebellion in the air, though....

(with thanks to City editor Jill Treanor)

Updated at 10.42am BST

10.21am BST

Britain's retailers have just enjoyed their strongest quarterly growth in a decade, according to the detail in today's retail sales figures.

The amount of goods purchased increasing by 1.8% in the three months to April, on a rolling 3-month to 3-month basis.

That's the highest reading since March 2004 and was the 14th consecutive month of three-month-on-three month growth in the quantity of goods bought.

That driven by the 6.9% annual surge in April (as flagged at 9.39am). The ONS said that all stores, apart from petrol stations, enjoyed a rise in sales volumes.

Notably the food sector posted its strongest year-on-year growth since January 2002, increasing by 6.3%. Feedback from food store retailers suggested that a better than expected Easter and better weather conditions helped to boost sales.

Updated at 10.28am BST

10.08am BST

Analysts at Berenberg reckon that today's minutes play a different tune than the Bank of England governor sang at the quarterly inflation report last week:

Last Wednesday, governor Mark Carney played down the idea of a rate-rise before next May's election.

Updated at 2.02pm BST

9.59am BST

Today's Bank of England minutes show that some members of its rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee are looking at the strong recovery and wondering if it's nearly time to raise interest rates.

The minutes of May's meeting of the MPC are online here.

They explain that the decision over whether to raise borrowing costs is becoming "more balanced" for some of the nine-strong committee.

The Bank's view is that rates will only rise "gradually and to a level materially below its pre-crisis average".

Some on the committee are wondering whether, in that case, they should start raising them sooner rather than later. Others are more focused on whether an early rate rise would cause long-term damage to the economy.

As the minutes put it:

It could be argued that the more gradual the intended rise in Bank Rate, the earlier it might be necessary to start tightening policy. Against that, if productive potential were in part related to the level of demand, then the earlier policy was tightened the greater the risk of incurring a substantial cost in foregone output.

Committee members placed different weights on these considerations and this was reflected in a variety of views on the appropriate path of monetary policy. The Committee would continue to refine its views as the economy evolved, and for some members the monetary policy decision was becoming more balanced.

However, the MPC remained united - saying that while there are no other inflationary pressures to worry about, they will wait to see "more evidence of slack* reducing" before raising rates.

* - spare capacity in the labour market

9.43am BST

This chart shows how the pound just jumped against the US dollar, driven by the jump in retail sales, and the news that some Bank of England policymakers are moving closer to voting to raise interest rates.

9.39am BST

Retail sales surge 6.9% year-on-year

UK retail sales have surged in April, and by more than expected, in another signal that the British economy remains strong.

Retail sales volumes jumped by 1.3% last month alone, twice as much as economists had forecast, driven by robust food sales over the Easter holidays.

That means sales volumes were 6.9% higher than in April 2012.

The late Easter (it fell in March last year) was expected to push up demand at retailers - but not by this much...

9.35am BST

The pound has jumped, hitting a two-week high of $1.6922 against the US dollar.

And it hit a new 16-month high against the euro, of 81.03p.

9.31am BST

Bank of England voted 9-0 to leave rates unchanged.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee voted 9-0 to leave interest rates at their record low of 0.5% at this month's meeting, minutes just released show.

But some members believed the decision on when to raise rates is "becoming more balanced" - a sign that some MPC members are turning more hawkish about the need to raise borrowing costs.

More to follow!

Updated at 9.32am BST

9.27am BST

The dividend paid to SSE shareholders has been rising steadily over the last 15 years, flags up Emily Gosden of the Telegraph.

Indeed. it's more than tripled -- from 25.7p in 1999 to 86.7p for last year.

And she's not convinced by the argument that last winter's price hike didn't help drive profits up:

9.21am BST

Nearly time for the latest Bank of England minutes, and the retail sales figures for April, at 9.30am.

Kit Juckes of Société Générale reckons retail sales picked up last month, partly due to the Easter holidays:

The late timing of Easter caused UK retail sales to be weak in March. So a rebound in April is likely. We're looking for a 0.6% bounce and for a lack of thrills from the MPC Minutes.

9.16am BST


Shares in French bank BNP Paribas have slipped 2% this morning, on reports that it's about to feel the full wrath of US regulators.

Bloomberg is reporting that US authorities are planning to impose $5bn in fines, and a temporary ban on transferring money in and out of America, for violating US sanctions.

The bank had previously said it expected a fine of at least $1bn, with analysts pencilling in a $3bn penalty.

A block on money transfers, if only temporary, could have serious consequences for BNPP.

“When your client has to go to a rival bank to get the most basic banking service, even for a few months, you’ll lose them,” Fred Cannon, head of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, told Bloomberg.

8.59am BST

Back on SSE's results, and the Press Association has focused on the drop in retail profits at the energy supplier:

Energy giant SSE today said annual profits from its energy supply arm fell by nearly a third and are unlikely to recover for two years after it announced a price freeze.

Operating profits from the business dropped by 32.2% to £246 million though the wider group saw adjusted pre-tax profits rise 9.6% to £1.55 billion.

SSE said its energy supply arm was hit by lower use of energy by customers during a mild winter and a higher cost of gas.

The group pledged earlier this year to freeze household gas and electricity tariffs until January 2016, but said this did not impact on the latest annual figures, for the year to the end of March.

SSE made the promise a day before regulator Ofgem announced plans to refer the energy sector for a full-scale competition probe.

Chief executive Alistair Phillips-Davies said the pledge had been "hugely popular".

"It remains the only such commitment available to customers and will mean we take a hit on retail profits over the next couple of years," he added.

8.55am BST

It's the end of an era at Carpetright.

The UK flooring firm's (very) long-serving executive chairman, Lord Harris, is stepping down this summer, after more than half a century in carpet retailing.

Lord Harris explains it is time to step aside:

"I will be 72 this year and shareholders will be aware that I have been planning a managed hand-over of my responsibilities for some time.

Wilf Walsh, the former CEO of Coral, is taking over.

But Martin Harris, Lord Harris's son, is stepping down as Group Development Director to pursue other interests, having once looked like the heir apparent at the company....

Updated at 8.56am BST

8.46am BST

Heads-up for eurozone crisis watchers - the FT's Peter Spiegel is about to discuss his brilliant series on how the euro was saved, on Radio 4. You'll be able to hear it later on iPlayer (could be tricky if you're not in the UK, though)..

8.43am BST

SSE's 9.6% jump in profits (despite that drop in retail earnings) haven't caused any alarm in the City -- where shares have dipped just 0.3%, or 6p, to £15.60.

And Burberry's record profits have also gone down well - shares are up 0.6%

8.36am BST

Burberry's new boss, Christopher Bailey, has begun his stint at the top of the fashion industry by reporting record profits for the last year, up 8% rise in line with expectations.

But Burberry also warned (again) that adverse currency movements are going to wipe millions of pounds off its revenues this year.

If the pound remains at its current level against the yen, Burberry's licensing revenue will be reduced by about £10m, it predicted. Sterling has gained 10% against the yen since last May, but broadly flat this year.

Bailey, who also remains as Burberry's chief creative officer, also warned of "macroeconomic uncertainties", but remains upbeat:

As we enter a new chapter, our teams are united and energised by the opportunities ahead - from unlocking Japan, to accelerating Beauty and further integrating the physical and digital to deliver distinctive experiences.

8.17am BST

SSE has hiked the dividend it pays to shareholders by 3.0% -- part of its policy to raise dividends at least as fast as inflation.

But it warned that future earnings face several risks, including:

  • the possibility of a freeze on retail energy prices being legislated upon in Great Britain after the 2015 general election;

....as the Labour party has pledged if it forms the next government.

8.10am BST

SSE's chairman Lord Smith insists that his company is part of the solution, not the problem, in the energy sector - after growing profits by almost 10% in the last year:

"SSE is listening to and helping customers with the longest ever household energy price freeze in the Great Britain market;we have well-defined plans for net investment of around £5.5bn over the next four years in maintaining, upgrading and building the electricity assets customers depend on; and we are committed to giving investors a fair return through an annual dividend that at least keeps pace with inflation.

"The issues facing the energy sector are very challenging. Nevertheless, customers, investors, regulators, politicians and SSE all want the same thing: an energy market that works for customers, and is trusted and seen to do so. We believe SSE is not part of the problem but part of the solution to meeting the energy needs of customers in Great Britain and Ireland."

8.04am BST

SSE posts 9.6% jump in profits, but retail earnings fall

Energy firm SSE has reignited the debate over the state of Britain's energy sector by posting a 9.6% surge in profits for the last financial year.

SSE, one of Britain's "Big Six" suppliers, made adjusted pre-tax profits of£1.55bn for the year to 31 March compared with £1.4bn a year earlier.

Operatinng profits at its wholesale division jumped almost 25%, while retail operating profits actually fell by 28.6%.

SSE blamed the "relatively mild winter in 2013/14" for its fall in retail profits; temperatures were warmer, and snowfalls were largely confined to the Scottish mountains.

But the company, which recently froze its prices until 2016, also shed around 370,000 customers last year. The total number of accounts fell to 9.1 million, from 9.47 million a year ago.

And has the Telegraph points out, these figures show the energy sector remains a profitable place to operate:

Updated at 8.38am BST

7.55am BST

Bank of England minutes; SSE results

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business.

Coming up today -- the minutes of the Bank of England's last monetary policy meeting will show whether any rate-setters are considering raising interest rates, in the face of a growing economy and hefty house price rises in London.

In an interview with Sueddeutsche Zeitung due to be published tomorrow (via Reuters) he said the ECB's loose monetary policy stance was appropriate to support the recovery but the risks should be borne in mind. Back with AstraZeneca, and here's someone backing the board against the Pfizer bid. Over to Greece where the political temperature is rising ahead of a second round of local European elections this weekend. Helena Smith reports: Greece heads to elections this weekend in brittle mood. As Giorgos Kaminis and Gabriel Sakellarides, the two candidates for the Athens mayoralty prepare to face each other in a live debate this evening, it is Golden Dawn, the far right party which has blossomed with the country’s economic crisis, that is dominating events. The extremist group’s surprisingly strong performance in the first round of last Sunday’s local and regional elections – at 16.1 % its own candidate for mayor Ilias Kasidiaris more than doubled the party’s 6.9% showing in national elections in 2012 – has sparked concerns across the political spectrum. Deputy prime minister Evangelos Venizelos, who heads the coalition government’s junior partner, Pasok, called the showing “deeply worrying.” “The big democratic question is the high percentages of Golden Dawn in the municipality of Athens and the Attica prefecture,” he said. “It is the urgent duty of all citizens and social forces that believe in democracy and human rights to forcefully fight the fascist-ization of political life.” But political expediency, ahead of Sunday’s runoff local ballot, has resulted in what today’s centre-left Ta Nea described as “surreptitious flirting” with Golden Dawn. Sakellarides, candidate for the vehemently anti-austerity radical left Syriza party in the race for Athens’ Town Hall, has (in a first for the left) gone out of his way to distinguish those who voted for Golden Dawn from the party itself. “We are not opening up to neo-Nazis … the 16 % of Athenians who voted for Kasidiaris are not neo-Nazis” he said before appealing to them to “change their mind” about how they would “protest about the situation we are living today.” Analysts are now in no doubt that it is the economy that poses the greatest challenge for the government. Despite the encouraging signs Greece has shown of late – its return to international markets, its improved fiscal figures and attraction of record numbers of tourists – Golden Dawn has capitalized on the seething resentment and rage of those now wanting to punish a system seen as the genesis of everything that is wrong with Greece. The middle class, which has been brought to its knees by the collapse of small and medium sized businesses, a barrage of taxes and the highest unemployment rate in the EU, has moved shockingly towards Golden Dawn with the governing centre right New Democracy party losing most to the extremists. Despite the imprisonment of a third of its leaders - and a judicial investigation that has focused on its underground activities as a criminal organization – the neo-fascists took around 9 % nationwide in Sunday’s poll. More shocking still, the group attracted large levels of support in bourgeois areas of the capital such as Kolonaki where backing for the party reached 13.7 %. “Golden Dawn’s appeal is no longer based on the anti-immigrant vote, it’s all about the economy,” said the political commentator Giorgos Kyrtsos, a New Democracy candidate in the upcoming euro elections. “If there is not a dynamic development of the economy in the next four to five months, after the tourist season, we will be in big, big trouble.” The stronger than expected eurozone consumer confidence figures will not necessarily stop the European Central Bank from acting next month, perhaps with an interest rate cut, analysts reckon. Martin van Vliet at ING said: The further brightening in consumers’ economic mood bodes well for consumer spending growth in the second quarter – and will undoubtedly be greeted with enthusiasm in Brussels ahead of this week's European parliamentary elections. However, consumer spending across the eurozone, albeit improving, has consistently lagged the recovery in consumer confidence in recent quarters. Consequently, we remain cautious on the strength of the upturn in consumer spending, with household deleveraging and subdued real disposable income growth set to continue to act as restraining factors. So while it is encouraging to see confidence continuing to move in the right direction, this is unlikely to stop the ECB from implementing further easing measures next month. The country breakdown is not yet available for May, but the confidence recovery in the Eurozone has not been confined to Northern European countries. Sentiment in most Southern European countries has also recovered strongly, despite the ongoing high unemployment backdrop. Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight said: Encouraging news for eurozone growth prospects with consumer confidence extending its upward trend in May and rising markedly to be at its highest level since October 2007. This suggests that the Ukraine/Russia crisis has still not worried consumers unduly, although it does appear to have impacted on business confidence in some countries, notably Germany. While the ECB will be encouraged by the marked rise in eurozone consumer confidence in May and may well see it as indicating that modest eurozone recovery remains intact despite disappointing GDP growth of 0.2% quarter-on-quarter in the first quarter, it is does not make it any less likely that the ECB will cut all of its interest rates at its June meeting (including taking the deposit rate into negative territory), very possibly as part of a package of stimulative measures aimed at preventing prolonged very low eurozone consumer price inflation and softening the euro. Back with the eurozone, and consumer confidence for May rose to its highest level in six and a half years. The European Commission's first estimate showed a figure of -7.1 points compared to April's revised -8.6 and expectations of an improvement to -8.2. For the whole of the EU, consumer confidence improved by 1.6 points to -4.1. Axa Investment Managers has become the latest to come out against AstraZeneca's rejection of the £55 a share Pfizer bid. Axa owns 4.5% and is the third biggest shareholder in Astra. Jim Stride, director and head of UK equities, said: AXA Investment Managers UK, acting in accordance with its fiduciary duty to clients, has met with the management teams of Pfizer and AstraZeneca in the recent past. We have also engaged in ongoing written and verbal communication. It is the view of AXA IM UK that the board of AstraZeneca should not prevent an offer from Pfizer of £55 per share from being put to the shareholders of the company. Many shareholders – but not necessarily all – will find this an attractive offer. Accordingly we believe that the board was arguably wrong and acted too hastily to dismiss the latest proposal from Pfizer. webTitle: FTSE rebounds after two days of losses but Morrisons slide continues

fields.standfirst: Markets lifted by strong start on Wall Street while retailers lifted by high street sales
fields.body:
As leading shares edged higher after two days of decline, a notable exception was Morrisons.

The supermarket group fell 4.5p to 205p, the biggest loser in the FTSE 100, after Deutsche Bank cut its rating from hold to sell, and despite analysts at Cantor Fitzgerald playing down the impact of a supermarket price war and suggesting Morrisons could be a target for a US predator.

The sector has been under pressure as the big four supermarkets continue to lose market share to discounters Aldi and Lidl, prompting them to begin their own price cuts. Deutsche said:

Morrisons share price has rallied 10% in the past two weeks, outperforming the FTSE 100 by 10%. It has out-performed Tesco by 3% and J Sainsbury (on a total return basis) by 1% over the same period. Neither incremental news flow nor fundamental valuation supports the recent share price move.
[The recent] deterioration in sales growth occurred over the crucial Easter period and before the 1 May launch of the price campaign "I'm your new cheaper Morrisons". Typically, it takes at least six months before the impact of price initiatives are reflected in volumes and in the meantime, price cuts should negatively impact value growth. As such, we expect no improvement in Morrisons' sales trend in the coming months.

Deutsche also played down bid talk:

A bid does not make sense at this level.
In our view, a potential bid at 275p per share (as reported in ThisisMoney.co.uk on 15 May) must be premised on one of two unlikely scenarios: 1) monetizing a material portion of Morrisons' property assets at the company's current estimate of market value of £9bn or 2) improving profitability materially from the 2014 2.8% our estimate earnings before interest and tax margin (low end of the guided range). We see limited scope for further capital expenditure cuts beyond those already announced.

But Cantor Fitzgerald's Mike Dennis issued a buy note on Morrisons and said the business could appeal to a US company because of the tax benefits, or could link up with a value store group such as Poundland:

Our industry view remains that: investors should see a positive upturn if sector trading margins only fall 40-60 basis points this year and that free cash flow improves as capital investment is significantly reduced and the current dividend payout is sustained or improved. Morrisons dividend yield is 6.5%, Sainsbury's 5.3% and Tesco's 4.8%, which are attractive given the improving consumer outlook.
We believe Morrisons is the most vulnerable to management and strategy change as US retailers consider the tax benefits of relocating in the UK and Europe. The Walgreens/Alliance Boots merger highlights the attractions of UK/European takeovers to US firms that want to generate lower global tax charges through invoicing and accounting for profits in lower tax countries. The other factor is the attraction of value stores (Poundland, B+M etc) whose store base and management teams could form part of the on-going consolidation and differentiation in the food retail sector. A period of lower positive food price inflation and some corporate and management changes could, in our view, lead to an improved sector outlook in 2014.

Tesco ended 2.25p lower at 303.8p and J Sainsbury dipped 1.8p to 337.7p.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished up 19.04 points at 6821.04 after earlier falling as low as 6782. The turnaround followed a strong opening on Wall Street ahead of the latest US Federal Reserve minutes.

Among the gainers, AstraZeneca added 111.5p to £44.20 on the hope - rightly or wrongly - that the Pfizer bid may not be completely dead.

Positive UK retail sales figures helped lift Sports Direct International 27p to 751p while Burberry rose 3p to £15.18 on an 8% rise in full year profits

Arm added 16p to 861p after a positive reaction to the chip designer's investor day on Tuesday.

Miners were mixed, with Antofagasta off 12.5p at 771p as it said the market continued to be challenging in the short term. But Anglo American added 13.5p to 1546.5p after CIBC put an outperform rating on the business.

Petrofac put on 26p to £12.20 after Barclays moved from underweight to equal weight but cut its price target from £16.55 to £15.

But BG fell 9p to 1261.5p despite positive news on a well test in Brazil by one of the gas group's partners. Liberum said:

Petrobras has announced overnight that it has completed testing a well on the Sagitário prospect (Petrobras 60%, BG 20%, Repsol Sinopec 20%). The results obtained have confirmed the discovery announced on 25 February 2013, when the well was still in the drilling phase. This is the first well to be drilled in block BM-S-50 and it is situated 194 km off the São Paulo coast, at a water depth of 1,871 meters located in the Santos Basin pre-salt. The consortium will proceed to evaluate the results.
Good news for BG. Too early for us to ascribe any value but confirms there is still upside to go for in Brazil.

A number of shares went ex-dividend, including HSBC, 8.6p lower at 618.5p, Intertek, off 35p at £28.91, and Compass, 7.5p lower at 986p.

Among the mid-caps utility group Telecom Plus jumped 149p or nearly 11% to £15.19 following a 25% rise in annual profits.

Ladbrokes was lifted 4.9p to 138.5p by vague bid talk. Playtech, the software specialist for the gaming industry, said at its annual meeting it was keen on "value enhancing acquisitions, joint ventures and partnerships, particularly focusing on regulated markets" and some traders suggested Ladbrokes as a possible target for the company and a private equity partner. Playtech put on 22.5p to 607p.

webTitle: EE launches rural phase of 4G rollout

fields.standfirst: Firm aims for service to reach 90% of population by December, despite warning last year that it may scale back ambitions
fields.body:
The village of Silverburn stands at the foot of the Pentland Hills south of Edinburgh and numbers just 65 inhabitants, but it is about to be plugged into EE's superfast mobile network, as the operator launches the rural phase of its 4G rollout.

EE on Wednesday said it would bring 4G to 2,588 rural and suburban locations. However, the group has pulled back from its ambition of reaching 95% of the population by December, and is now aiming to get to 90%, up from 73% currently.

The company warned last Christmas that it might have to scale back its rural ambitions, blaming the telecoms watchdog Ofcom's plans to increase annual rental charges for mobile spectrum.

Having already connected the major towns and cities, the operator is now entering the more expensive phase of its rollout, targeting settlements of less than 10,000, which will bring it within range of more than 3.5 million people.

EE boss Olaf Swantee said: "We are committed to adapting our network to make 4G available where it matters most, with a focus on more rural areas, transport links and offering our customers the best network experience."

With speeds typically up to 10 megabits per second, in many villages the mobile network could prove a better way of accessing the internet, particularly for high bandwidth activities such as watching videos, than fixed-line broadband.

The operator is also sending its engineers out to wire up motorways and A roads, in the hope of reducing the number of dropped calls made from moving vehicles. The wiring up of the 117-mile-long M25 around London is already complete, as are 47 train stations and 22 airports in the UK.

The number of 4G customers on EE's network has now reached 3.6 million, with 1.6 million joining this year alone. At the last count, the group, which also includes the Orange and T-Mobile brands, had 25 million customers and the vast majority were on 3G plans.

But interest in 4G has now reached a tipping point, with 55% of those joining or upgrading opting for superfast connections rather than a contract with Orange or T-Mobile, which do not offer 4G.

The rate of signings is faster than at Vodafone, which has just begun building its 4G network and this week announced that it had added 137,000 superfast customers since Christmas to reach a total of 637,000. It promised to reach 99% population coverage within two years.

webTitle: Retail recovery under way as consumers spend more and worry less

fields.bodyText: Retailers have not had it this good since Tony Blair was prime minister. Spending in shops, stores and online was almost 7% higher last month than it was in April 2013. That's the highest rate of growth since May 2004. Back then, the strength of consumer demand was enough to spur the Bank of England into action. Official interest rates, which had begun the year at 3.75%, were raised from 4% to 4.25% in May 2004. There were two further quarter-point increases in June and August taking bank rate to 4.75%. Expect something a tad more leisurely this time. The minutes of the Bank's monetary policy committee meeting held this month show that Threadneedle Street is edging closer to raising borrowing costs from their emergency level of 0.5%. Some of the nine members of the monetary policy committee believe the decision is becoming more balanced. This seems a statement of the obvious given that the economy is growing at an annual rate of 3% and London has a stonking great property bubble. Rates were cut to 0.5% during the emergency conditions of early 2009, when there were justifiable fears that the global economy was about to plunge into a second Great Depression. While it could be argued that the economy currently is enjoying a "sugar rush" as a result of the recovery in the housing market, it is in better shape than it was five years ago. Retail sales are a sign of a more buoyant mood among consumers, who see an end coming to the squeeze on spending power and are much less fearful of losing their jobs than they were during the period of flatlining that followed the recession. The Bank has helped create that mood in two ways. It introduced the Funding for Lending scheme in 2012, which was intended to give banks incentives to lend to businesses and households, but really worked by reviving the moribund mortgage market. And since last August, it has used forward guidance to reassure companies and individuals thinking of taking out loans that the MPC will not be trigger happy when it comes to raising borrowing costs. It is prepared to let the recovery run until all the spare capacity in the economy is used up, relying on customised measures to rein in the housing market. At some point, the message from the Bank will change. But not just yet.

webTitle: Timing of mortgage rate rise looks less certain after Bank of England meeting

fields.standfirst: Minutes of May meeting show policymakers disagreed over the strength of the recovery and when to raise rates
fields.body:
The prospect of a rise in mortgage rates next spring looks more uncertain after Bank of Engand policymakers appeared to be split over when to end the UK's five years of cheap credit.

The nine-strong monetary policy committee was divided at its meeting earlier this month after a sharp fall in unemployment and rapid GDP growth contrasted with low average wage rises and a lack of lending to small businesses.

The first sign of major split on the MPC since governor Mark Carney took up his post last summer sent the pound higher as investors bet that interest rates would rise earlier than predicted.

Economists had expected the Bank to begin raising rates early next year, but minutes of the MPC's April meeting showed that policymakers disagreed over the strength of the recovery and when to raise rates back to more normal levels.

Some committee members, including Bank insider Paul Fisher and former City economist David Miles, are known to be doveish supporters of freezing rates until next year. Chief economist Spencer Dale and Ben Broadbent, who is soon to become a deputy governor, have voiced concerns that delays in raising interest rates will allow the economy to overheat.

According to the minutes, members held different views on the capacity of firms to expand output without raising wages, whether the rise in self-employment represented millions of workers being under-employed; and the extent to which an expansion in cheap labour undermined hopes of productivity gains.

Nevertheless they voted unanimously to keep base rates at 0.5% and keep the stock of bonds bought by the Bank under its quantitative easing programme at £375bn and signalled that when rates rise it will be a slow process, stopping well before the previous 4% to 5% average.
